snippet: The U.S.T.A.’s rules for younger players continue to divide members of the tennis community, who often disagree about the best methods for attracting young athletes to the sport.
abstract: United States Tennis Assn’s rules for younger players, which include the use of low-compression balls and shorter rackets, continue to divide members of the tennis community; critics say requirements make tournaments more confusing for parents and less profitable and more challenging to coordinate for organizers.

byline.original: By MARY PILON and ANDREW W. LEHREN

lead_paragraph: The U.S.T.A.’s rules for younger players continue to divide members of the tennis community, who often disagree about the best methods for attracting young athletes to the sport.

headline.main: Modified Training for Children Stirs New Debates
headline.print_headline: Modified Training for Children Stirs New Debates
